body_content.explanation: a measurement that shows the number of hydrogen atoms that can combine with one atom of a particular chemical element to make a compound, used to describe how easily an element can connect in a chemical way with others:
examples: His theory was that carbon had a combining power (valency) of four or two and a unique capacity for joining itself to other atoms of its own kind.
Sodium is useful in a great many compounds as a substitute for one of the two atoms of hydrogen (also valence 1) in a variety of acids.

body_content.explanation: A verb's valency or valence is the number of noun phrases with which it combines. :
examples: Many verbs can have a different valency depending on the meaning in which they are being used.
A verb such as "hand", with a subject, an object, and an indirect object, as in "she handed me the plate", has a valency of three.
These generic verbs are excellent models for analogy to other verbs of the same valency.
Valence is a property of verbs indicating the number of arguments a verb requires to make a clause.
